Fred C. Dobbs.Action: Tearing up a winning lottery ticket out of frustration, appearing disheveled and destitute, begging for money on the street.
Not recognizing or capitalizing on a winning opportunity (lottery ticket), showing lack of foresight or planning.
Throws water into the boy's face, then tips him a coin.
Offers a cigarette to his companion and exchanges a friendly sign.
Considers buying a lottery ticket but does so somewhat dismissively and brusquely; uses dismissive language about the boy’s face.
Weights the coin carefully before deciding to buy the lottery ticket, indicating attention to detail.
Engages in a small social interaction by offering a cigarette confidently.
Cuts his belt three notches tighter, showing practical self-management and awareness of physical needs.
Attempts to find steady work, moving from place to place looking for opportunities.
Realizes and articulates the racial and social limitations that block his economic progress.
Asks strangers for money repeatedly, showing dependence on charity.
Expresses cynicism and frustration about the environment making it hard to succeed, but takes no apparent effective action to improve his situation.
Politely accepts a coin from a man when asking for a 'dive'.
Considers whether to indulge in a small luxury (barber's service) and ultimately decides in favor, showing some self-care and appreciation.
Carefully studies his reflection and pays the barber generously with a liberal tip.
Thrusts the coin into his pants pocket and confidently walks off.
Considers carefully whether to indulge in a minor extravagance (the barber’s hand cream) and then decides to do so with a liberal tip, showing deliberation and control.
Studies himself in the mirror from various angles to ensure a good appearance.
Asks a stranger for money, then apologizes sincerely and promises not to bother him again once he realizes the man had already given him money multiple times.
Fails to recognize the White Suit as the same person who gave him money several times, focusing only on the money and not the man's face.
Politely promises the White Suit not to bother him again after being reproached.
Accepts money from the white suit and thanks him sincerely.
Turns on his heel and walks rapidly up the street alone after receiving help.
Asks a man for spare change calling him 'brother', showing an attempt at friendliness or camaraderie.
Does not insist or linger when refused help, quickly moves on.
Clinks two tostons together thoughtfully before moving on.
Accepts money from a stranger but intends to make his own way without assistance.
Approaches strangers asking for spare change.
Considers a job offer from McCormick and inquires about pay.
Works sixteen to eighteen hours a day and offers a bonus to encourage finishing early.
Expresses financial desperation and admits having no money even for food or drink.
Nods to acknowledge a debt owed, engages in tense interaction but remains involved with partners.
Offers practical solution despite poor conditions, suggesting a rat- and scorpion-infested place for shelter to manage costs.
Exchanges scowls and tense moments with partners, with no apparent conciliatory or friendly behavior.
Knows to meet at the cantina by a certain time, shows up prepared to collect money owed.
Engages in tense exchanges, showing suspicion and scowling at others, but remains in control of the situation.
Counts money carefully, is aware of limited funds, and suggests a cheap but unpleasant lodging.
Appears resigned to poor conditions (rats, scorpions, cockroaches) without complaining or attempting better alternatives.
Accepts sleeping in a poor, rat- and scorpion-infested place rather than being choosy, showing adaptability and pragmatism.
Listens carefully to old man's story about the gold, indicating interest and willingness to gather information before acting.
Stops undressing to listen attentively to the old man’s explanation about gold and greed.
Shows internal struggle to restrain himself from desires and greed.
Expresses desire to take only as much gold as he needs, even if there's a million bucks worth lying around.
Shows awareness of human nature and the corrupting power of gold, indicating some self-awareness and realism.
Expresses a strong desire to only take as much money as worth it, showing restraint and prudence in dealing with potential wealth.
Feels the lure of gold has changed men fundamentally and recognizes the danger of losing oneself, indicating self-awareness and insight.
Appears nostalgic and somewhat defeated, describing himself as 'an old gnawed bone' who feels the spirit is gone.
Talks about the hard physical labor of prospecting and the necessity of sharing expenses, showing practical awareness of the difficulties.
Appears emotionally affected by past failed ventures and pessimistic about prospecting, which may indicate diminished confidence.
Discusses gold's influence on a man, expressing that it depends on the person's character rather than the gold itself.
Shows suspicion about Pat McCormick's behavior and the company he's with.
Discusses philosophically about gold not being inherently evil or a curse, suggesting thoughtful reflection.
Engages in conversation but fails to observe or respond to Curtin's distracted attention, showing lack of situational awareness.
Takes money from McCormick's wallet to pay the bartender and urges to leave before the law arrives.
Shows eagerness to get liquor with the group.
Suggests involving the old man in gold prospecting and values his experience despite his age.
Considers the old man too old to carry but still wants his help.
Suggests gold digging as a practical way to make money, comparing it favorably to waiting for a break.
Recognizes the value of an experienced old man for prospecting and suggests recruiting him.
Admits he doesn't know much about prospecting personally.
Acknowledges the need to invest last money into tools and provisions, aware of the risks involved in mining and needing weapons.
Refuses to participate in a customary lottery-related payment despite social pressure and superstitious warning.
Expresses misunderstanding and irritation about the lottery custom, showing a lack of social tact or understanding.
Gives a lottery ticket as a present to a poor boy with his blessing.
Smiles and thanks the boy graciously after giving the ticket.
Identifies a winning lottery ticket, understands its value, and shares the news confidently with Curtin.
Generously gives the boy a dime as a present for the lottery ticket.
Speaks with enthusiasm and confidence about the prospect of profiting from the lottery winnings.
Asleep on the train while others are actively studying the map and discussing the route and prospects.
Appears physically and mentally disengaged during planning, showing lack of alertness and preparation.
Follows Howard's lead by grabbing his gun and participating actively in defending against the bandit attack on the train.
Claims credit by saying 'I got these off tom' suggesting a confident and skillful shooting during the attack.
Confidently claims to have gotten one more than Curtin and talks about shooting accuracy including narrowly missed shot at bandit
Misses a target due to train jolting although he had good aim
Shares observations enthusiastically with group, showing engagement and focus
Excitedly shows Curtin and Howard the gold vein he found, tries to involve them in discovery.
Seizes Howard abruptly by the arm to show the gold, ignoring Howard's lack of enthusiasm.
Identifies gold veins in the rocks by testing with water and shows excitement about the find.
Attempts to convince Howard about the value of the gold, showing some confidence and initiative.
Possibly overly optimistic about the quality and quantity of the gold without full verification from partners.
Crying, acting tears to the mixture of sweat and blood that gets into his eyes and rolls off his chin.
Displays emotional breakdown, cries due to stress and physical weariness during hardship.
Follows instructions to lie down quietly when ordered, indicating some situational compliance.
Howls and threatens to smash things, acts aggressively and impulsively.
Picks up and throws a rock with practiced ease in a tense situation.
Shows rash, uncontrolled behavior that causes others to restrain him.
Makes a light-hearted comment: 'I'd sure hate to play poker with you, old-timer.'
Tries his best to imitate the actions of the old man (Howard), showing willingness to learn and cooperate.
Asks 'When're we going to s- ing it?' indicating impatience and possible distrust or anxiety about sharing or waiting.
Tries his best to imitate Howard's actions in washing the sand for gold extraction.
Asks when they will be dividing the gold, showing impatience or eagerness rather than understanding the process.
Acknowledges Curtin's help in saving him and says 'I owe you my life, partners'
Sits up and tests his arms and legs after being rescued, showing concern for his own wellbeing
Remains unconscious after a tunnel cave-in and is rescued by others.
Tests his arms and legs after being pulled out, indicating self-assessment of condition.
Expresses gratitude toward his partners for saving his life.
Follows Howard's instructions closely during gold division.
Confidently announces detailed personal plans for after the work is done, including a visit to a Turkish bath, buying new clothes, and dining out.
Spends considerable time fantasizing about leisure and comfort rather than focusing on current practical concerns.
Flings money into the fire after being called a hog, refusing to be insulted.
Flings the dust of gold away impulsively after weighing it.
Wakes up alert and reacts quickly to the scream of a tiger, puts on shoes and arms himself with a revolver.
Hides in shadows and confronts Howard cautiously when hearing him approach.
Keeps his face averted and passes Curtin without any words being exchanged.
Talks angrily to Howard, accusing partners sarcastically.
Continues a monologue revealing frustration and isolation.
Keeps his face averted and refuses to engage with Curtin, showing avoidance and potential paranoia.
Talks angrily to Howard and complains about his partners, indicating poor teamwork and social skills.
Monologues to himself and expresses frustration, possibly revealing internal conflict but lacking productive problem-solving.
Accuses others of trying to deceive him, is highly suspicious and paranoid.
Refuses to delegate or share tasks, insists on handling provisions himself despite risks.
Expresses fear of bandits and mistrust towards companions, but fails to plan effectively to mitigate risks.
Stalks off after confrontation instead of resolving conflict constructively.
Covers Curtin with a gun, threatens him to put his hands up, takes away Curtin's gun.
Mocks Curtin's claim about a Gila monster under a rock, sarcastically challenges Curtin to stick his hand under it.
Suddenly covers Curtin with a gun, taking control of the situation with confidence.
Snorts and mocks Curtin's explanation about the Gila monster, showing skepticism but remaining calm.
Threatens Curtin not to make a move and maintains a position of power during the confrontation.
Sweating with fear, aims wildly and threatens to kill Curtin.
Suggests dealing harshly with a stranger by feeding them plums too hard to digest to discourage their presence.
Agrees with harsh treatment and exclusion of others from the group.
Suggests dealing with a suspicious person by misleading him to eat bad plums to incapacitate him.
Proposes direct confrontation without considering risks properly.
Cooperates with group strategy and accepts cautious advice from Howard, showing some flexibility.
Tests the potatoes with a knife to see if they are cooked enough before eating.
Lies sprawled out watching every move Cody makes, showing cautious vigilance.
Advises the newcomer to leave and return to where he came from, showing bluntness but also a strategic view on safety.
Does not offer help to the newcomer or actively engage positively, seeming indifferent or dismissive.
Gives Curtin a long wink and confidently talks about his hunting skills and the good hides, implying he knows the area well and can make a profit.
Speaks with some confidence about the land and game, but there is no clear indication of actual success or smart planning here.
Kicks mules lightly after feeding them corn and pats their noses.
Proposes to start a quarrel with another person in order to provoke a violent reaction and then kill him.
Suggests to start a quarrel with another character to provoke a reaction and then ambush him.
Plants his fist into someone's face with enough force to knock them down and intimidate others.
Accuses a man of stealing water and shows aggressive vigilance over resources.
Exhibits irritable and bullying behavior that causes others to feel embarrassed or uncomfortable.
Asserts his intention to stay despite warnings, showing determination and confidence.
Indicates awareness of the danger and the need for mutual trust among partners to avoid violent conflict.
Expresses doubt about others' readiness and capability to act decisively ('you two haven't the looks').
Engages in negotiation and cautious dialogue about options involving violence, betrayal, and partnership.
Suggests making a new person a partner to avoid future conflict and keep control of the claim transparent among all involved.
Discusses strategy about dealing with an outsider, showing awareness of social dynamics and potential threats.
Shows some paranoia and eagerness to protect the claim, which may cloud judgment but also shows cautious thinking.
Draws his gun quickly and confronts Cody, accusing him of being an informer; displays readiness to act decisively.
Obsesses about the idea of an informer to the point of distraction and hostility, despite others urging calm and cooperation.
Refuses to heed other characters' advice to think and plan together, staying fixated on accusations.
Demonstrates a sense of situational awareness about dangers from bandits and informers, suggesting some understanding of threats.
Suggests and helps prepare a defensible position by wrapping up belongings and filling buckets with water for defense.
Follows instructions to help fortify their position in anticipation of an attack.
Shouts 'Stop or I shoot' to potential threat, displaying suspicion and hostility rather than friendliness.
Does not attempt to escalate by reaching for weapon immediately, shows some restraint.
Threatens the bandits with his gun to keep his health and refuses to hand over his gun without cause.
Maintains a hostile and distrustful stance towards the supposed police, demanding badges aggressively.
Challenges the supposed police to show badges, showing skepticism and assertiveness.
Waves his gun threateningly to keep the bandits at bay, displaying confidence and tactical awareness.
Refuses to give up his gun despite negotiation attempts from the bandits, indicating stubbornness and self-preservation.
Acts impulsively by waving a gun at potentially unknown hostile men, risking escalation.
Fails to deescalate the situation peacefully and does not attempt to verify the legitimacy of the men, showing poor judgment.
Fires a long shot accurately at bandits, causing them to retreat.
Bandits accuse Dobbs of trickery and disbelieve his skill, implying possible questionable tactics or overconfidence.
Expresses confidence in having the bandits on the run and questions concern about counterattack.
Shows awareness of tactical situation and cautious about enemy attacks.
No clear action showing planning or adapting tactics in dialogue, somewhat passive during strategic discussion.
Comments that the bandits leaving quickly is doing them a favor, noting soldiers could be a nuisance if they started asking questions and nosing around.
Encourages aggressive action: 'Go get to Sic 'om Tige! Chew ’em into pits and don't spit ‘em out -- swallow ‘em.'
Expresses relief and self-pity: 'Am I happy, am I. Fellers, tell you the truth I was already chowing dirt.'
Commenting on the soldiers as a potential nuisance but appreciating their absence as favorable to their plans.
Encourages others aggressively ('Go get te Sic 'om Tige! Chew tom into pits and don't spit tem out'), showing confident and assertive leadership.
States 'I was already chowing dirt,' implying awareness of danger and a realistic assessment of his vulnerability or situation.
Makes assumptions about providence or fate regarding lives, which may indicate a less rational or superstitious mindset.
Examines a snapshot and comments on it thoughtfully.
Shows interest in personal effects but does not display further analysis or strategy based on findings.
Suggests calling it quits to avoid further danger and hopes to leave sooner rather than later.
Shows confusion and skepticism about Howard's plan to cover up their mining activity.
Calls out to the rattlesnake respectfully, choosing to avoid conflict and not harm it, demonstrating situational awareness.
Rejects the idea of giving a fourth share of goods to Cody’s widow and kid, showing a short-sighted and selfish approach to partnership and fairness.
Offers tobacco to the Indians and accepts theirs in return, sharing in a cultural custom.
Politely say 'Muchas gracias' when accepting the tobacco from Indians.
Produces his tobacco pouch and shares tobacco with the Indians, participating in a social exchange respectfully.
Questions why everyone doesn't smoke their own tobacco, showing some skepticism or lack of understanding of social customs.
Laughs off the Indian’s gratitude and refuses to acknowledge any debt owed.
Cuts in roughly, pushing through the Indians to refuse their hospitality and insist they cannot stay.
Laughs off the Indian's gratitude and refuses to acknowledge any debt.
Cuts in and roughly pushes through the Indians to reject their hospitality.
Shakes hands confidently with Howard, gives practical advice and friendly warnings.
Uses slang and humor that might undermine authority but shows social ease and situational awareness.
Complains bitterly about the burros, showing impatience and lack of empathy for their plight.
Refuses to continue the journey and offers to let others go on without him, showing detachment and shirking responsibility.
Complains about the burros and their tendency to stray and damage their packs, showing frustration rather than problem-solving.
Decides to stop for the night and refuses to take responsibility for the old man's burros, abdicating responsibility and initiative.
Questions the intelligence of the old man for entrusting his goats to them, showing skepticism but also awareness of their own limits.
Assertively challenges Curtin's decision and expresses confidence in his own physical capability to travel far, indicating strong self-assurance.
Behaves aggressively and domineeringly, threatening Curtin and escalating conflict, which may undermine group cohesion and decision-making.
Realizes that they now have control over the packs and laughs confidently about outsmarting the old man by keeping all the goods.
Mocks others by calling them 'bonehead' or 'dumbhead' to assert his own cleverness.
Laughs loudly and seems somewhat unrestrained, suggesting impulsiveness rather than careful planning.
Insists on doing things alone, rejects help from Curtin confidently.
Dismisses Curtin's serious concern about respecting the old man's hard work and rights.
Accuses Curtin of planning to kill him and steal their goods, showing paranoia but also alertness to danger.
Draws his gun quickly and confidently to control a confrontation, demanding Curtin raise his hands, showing decisiveness and self-protection.
Smiles with satisfaction after controlling the situation, indicating confidence in his manipulative or intimidating tactics.
His own gun unexpectedly goes off as he reaches for Curtin's gun, suggesting lack of carefulness or a critical mistake in handling weapons.
Halts and stands aside on the trail letting the pack train pass, showing situational awareness and restraint.
Engages in a tense standoff, laughing off threats and issuing bets, showing confidence but possibly reckless bravado.
Leads the pack train during a difficult journey, taking initiative in a leadership position despite exhaustion.
Laughs when Curtin draws his gun in startled defense.
Relieves Curtin of his gun after confirming he is asleep.
Kicks Curtin in the ribs repeatedly to rouse and intimidate him.
Expresses intention to act on his plan alone, rejecting Curtin's authority.
Observes Curtin carefully and waits for the right moment to disarm him without immediate violence.
Relieves Curtin of his gun stealthily, indicating tactical awareness and patience.
Kicks Curtin to arouse him and maintain control, demonstrating physical assertiveness and control over the situation.
Gives orders firmly and clearly, showing confidence and decisiveness.
Laughs after Curtin draws his gun, suggesting possible underestimation of danger or emotional instability.
After shooting Curtin and seeing him motionless, Dobbs hesitates to check if he is really dead, showing uncertainty.
Uses a burning stick as a torch to search the bush, showing resourcefulness.
Doubts his own actions (hesitates to be sure Curtin is dead), then shoots again to be certain, demonstrating cautiousness and decisiveness.
Throws away the gun carelessly and mutters, indicating possible frustration or lack of composure.
Recognizes the fire does not give enough heat and regrets not gathering more firewood earlier, indicating poor planning.
Decides not to go back into the bush at night to look for Curtin and instead plans to dig a hole in the morning, showing sensible risk assessment.
Expresses inner torment over conscience, calling it nonsense yet feeling sickened by the fussing about it.
Becomes impatient and lashes out savagely at the pack animals when a sack slips.
Considers leaving a fellow companion behind, rationalizing that nature will take care of him and no one would likely find him.
Shows internal conflict and hesitation about what to do with the body in the bush, debating practical consequences and outcomes.
Exhibits impatience and frustration, savagely kicks sacks blaming the burro unfairly.
Forgets important tool (leaves spade on the ground) in anticipation, then stops shortly after starting to use it.
Thinks pragmatically that leaving the body hidden is acceptable because nature will dispose of it and bandits won't likely bury him; shows some practical reasoning.
His hands start trembling and he totters in his tracks from fear at a scream, temporarily losing composure.
Pulls himself together and attempts to shake off his fear and continue forward.
Has to untangle and repack a fallen burro's pack to get it back on its feet, managing to succeed despite difficulties.
Runs ahead and behind the burros to keep the animals on the right trail, working hard to control them.
Initially nearly loses control and burdened by his fear and the burros' disobedience.
Gropes mentally into a problem, tries to stay calm and solve it, comes up with a solution.
Laughs delightfully after shooting someone, mocks the situation rather than showing serious reflection.
Successfully returns to find camp and pack animals intact, suggesting some situational awareness.
Studies the map carefully and tries to understand his location despite confusion and fatigue.
Shows hesitation and slow comprehension of what he reads on the map indicating mental dullness.
Realizes the river on the map is dry in winter, demonstrating situational awareness.
Reacted with frustration and aggression by viciously kicking the burros and shouting.
Pretends to have no money and cleverly answers Gold Hat's questions to avoid suspicion.
Takes his time to appear calm and unafraid, managing his behavior strategically in a tense situation.
Claims to have friends coming shortly to support him though the narrator questions the truth of this claim.
Interacts cooperatively with the Gold Hat by allowing him to inspect the packs and answers honestly that the packs contain hides.
Prepares to flee by checking and tightening the burros' packs, showing care for his belongings but little concern for others.
Attempts to deceive the bandit Gold Hat about having friends nearby who do not actually appear to be close.
Checks the packs on the burros carefully and tightens straps to secure the load before possibly fleeing.
Prepares himself physically by tightening his belt and pulling his pants higher, indicating readiness to act quickly.
Engages with the bandit but ultimately is in a precarious position, suggesting some lack of confidence or control over the situation.
Attempts to confront bandits and protect his burros by drawing and firing his gun.
His gun misfires repeatedly, leaving him defenseless at a critical moment.
Seeks alternative means of defense by reaching for a machete tied to a burro.
Fails to secure the machete before being struck with a stone, leading to his defeat.
Holds up pants with his belt, appearing disorganized and reliant on external means for basic functionality.
Involved in chaotic situations with bandits and confusion, does not take decisive or effective control of events.
Observed more as a passive figure amidst dangerous circumstances, showing limited initiative or confidence.
Is reported murdered by bandits, leaving his goods behind but no evidence of protective or skilled behavior prior to death.
His belongings are found safely stored, suggesting some prior planning or organization.
Does not appear or act in this excerpt; no demonstration of skill, intelligence, or confidence.
Throws water in a poor boy's face who is trying to sell lottery tickets, then laughs and dismisses him harshly.
Tips the coffee proprietor cinco centavos after paying for coffee.
Asks a stranger for spare change ('Brother, can you spare a dive?'), and is shown receiving money from a white man.
Expresses bitterness and resentment about racial discrimination and hardship in Mexico, using sarcastic and harsh language toward the social system.
Turns away from the bench after reflection and bitter commentary, showing withdrawal rather than engagement.
Helps carry heavy boards and works hard alongside others under difficult conditions.
Addresses fellow workers casually, makes a dry comment about the heat.
Takes initiative to hurry across the street toward the ferry landing, responding promptly when urged to act quickly.
Enters a new situation calmly and interacts with others, such as greeting and organizing four men to board.
Works hard physically on the construction of a derrick, demonstrating physical capability and perseverance.
Complains about the extreme heat and discomfort on the derrick but continues working.
Accepts uncomfortable living conditions ('full of rats and scorpions and cockroaches') without complaint, showing practical tolerance.
Listens attentively with Curtin to the old man telling stories and information about gold in Mexico, indicating interest and openness.
Stops undressing to listen attentively to the old man speaking about gold mining and its impacts.
Feels the lure and obsession with gold leading to a loss of sense of values and character, indicating internal conflict.
Takes money from McCormick's wallet when McCormick is begging and defeated, counts it carefully and shares with Curtin, then quickly decides to leave before the law arrives.
Negotiates a deal in the mine, offering twenty-five percent, believing he can make it thirty, showing some understanding of self-interest and profit margins.
Appears impatient or desperate when asking about getting liquor, hinting at possible dependency or distraction.
Refuses to give lottery ticket seller a customary tip and shows suspicion toward the custom.
Expresses concern about money and surviving by investing in tools and weapons, discussing plans with others.
Howls aggressively and threatens to smash something; shows impatience and hostility to others.
Defends himself against accusations of being untrustworthy, insists he is not likely to betray others.
Acknowledges the difficulty of trust among the group and suggests cutting the proceeds to relieve suspicion.
Accuses another character of having a 'dirty filthy mind' in response to suspicion about hiding treasure.
Talks about personal plans involving self-care and enjoying comforts like baths and nice clothes, smiling and enjoying the thought
Argues for demanding more money for his share.
Dismisses others' modest estimates as 'small potatoes'.
Suggests demanding half again what others get, showing assertiveness in negotiations.
Appears to push for a larger share without clear strategic reasoning visible in the excerpt.
Takes the dust/gold offered by Curtin, weighs it in his hand carefully.
Suddenly flings the dust into the fire because he doesn't like being told to be a hog.
Confronts Howard cautiously at night, shows suspicion but does not accuse or attack.
Approaches Howard and offers help regarding the burros, showing some trust and willingness to cooperate.
Puts his shoe back on and prepares to leave the tent suspiciously when Curtin is absent; furrows brow with suspicion
Grunts and turns into the tent when Howard tries to motivate teamwork
Talks to himself warning others not to try to deceive him, indicating mistrust
Carefully hiding sacks of precious dust and counting them in secret.
Becomes suspicious of others' actions, showing vigilance and wariness.
Sharp and commanding tone when questioning Curtin's whereabouts, showing assertiveness.
Accuses Howard and Curtin of plotting against him, expresses suspicion and hostility loudly
Refuses to entrust his dust to others due to fear of bandits and distrust
Stalks off angrily when his concerns are dismissed
Sweats nervously showing fear; aims gun wildly and shouts threats without controlling the situation.
Almost fires at Curtin but is immediately disarmed because of poor control and impulsiveness.
No direct action or statement from Dobbs in this excerpt; no indication of competence or incompetence.
Suggests pushing a man off a rock and claiming it was an accident.
Invites the stranger over to the fire and speaks politely to him.
Suggests pushing a stranger off a rock to make it look like an accident instead of directly shooting him.
Insists on confronting the stranger by inviting him over to the fire despite his suspicions.
Takes the pot of potatoes from the fire, shakes it, and tests the potatoes with a knife to see if they are cooked enough.
Lies sprawled out watching every move Cody makes, not offering to help but observing silently.
Offers food and utensils to Curtin, saying 'help yourself, partner'
Says 'no trespassing around here' and warns others as if guarding territory
Gives Curtin a long wink
Casually shares information about good hunting ground with others
Allows Howard and Curtin to have their turns after he rests, shows consideration.
Irritatedly accuses Cody of stealing water without proof, shows suspicion and aggression.
Sleeps properly after assigning watch duty, showing some trust and routine in camp management.
Accuses another character of stealing water with irritability rather than gathering clear evidence first.
Shows ignorance about the difficulty of getting water, indicating lack of preparation or understanding of situation challenges.
Decides to fetch water himself after the altercation, demonstrating some initiative.
Accuses a stranger of stealing water and threatens violence.
Displays aggressive and suspicious behavior toward others.
Acknowledges the danger of being bumped off but insists on playing openly and taking risks for the stakes involved.
Acknowledge risks realistically and articulates consequences of violent action among partners, suggesting rational consideration of alternatives.
Shows awareness of potential dangers and attempts to engage openly with partners, aiming for clear communication.
Appears hesitant or conflicted about taking decisive action when confronted with threats, which may signal lack of assertiveness.
Expresses suspicion and resistance to including a stranger as a partner; wants to ensure no one takes advantage of the group; insists on clear agreements with all partners.
Acknowledges the need to resolve the situation among themselves and act decisively about the outsider's participation.
Admits to liking being taken advantage of
Stops the group suspiciously and draws his revolver
Accuses Cody of being an informer and points gun at him
Accuses Cody of being an informer and threatens him with a gun.
Repeats accusations despite group urging to stop and work together.
Shouts a warning 'Stop or I shoot' when noticing potential bandits approaching, showing alertness and readiness to act.
Makes no attempt to immediately draw his heavy revolver but warns first, demonstrating some restraint and measured response.
His jaw hangs in surprise upon seeing someone approaching, indicating a momentary lapse in composure.
Fires a shot to protect the group from bandits, taking initiative and risking his safety.
Keeps his own watch during a confrontation, showing concern for personal possessions in a tense moment.
Expresses a grim resolve to fight to the death, showing a willingness to sacrifice himself and take as many enemies down with him as possible.
Dismisses any chance of mercy or negotiation, suggesting a hardened, distrustful attitude toward the enemy.
Expresses willingness to fight to the death, shows determination to take down as many enemies as possible.
Makes a fatalistic statement about survival chances and torture without suggesting a clear plan or alternative.
Expresses suspicion that the bandits' approach might be a trick to lure them out and get them.
His warning to Curtin about the potential trick is ignored, leading potentially to danger.
Looks at young woman's tender, smiling photograph with a noticeable expression
Comments on the photograph with slight appreciation ('Not bad, not bad')
Produces his tobacco pouch and offers tobacco to the visiting Indians, accepting their tobacco in return.
Comments that he does not have tobacco to give, showing some reluctance.
Produces his tobacco pouch and participates in the tobacco exchange ritual with the Indians, facilitating a peaceful interaction.
Expresses worry or negativity about their luck and situation, calling it bad luck rather than taking proactive measures.
Pushes forcefully through the Indians, showing assertiveness and determination.
Opposes taking the packs along due to fear they will be discovered, showing strategic caution and awareness of risks.
Expresses anxiety plainly on his face, indicating internal stress and possible lack of calm confidence.
Responds angrily and aggressively when challenged about travel plans, uses harsh language and threatens physical confrontation.
After initial hostility, unloads his burro and receives a handshake from Curtin, indicating some level of cooperation.
Casually jokes about finishing a meal of roast turkey and tequila, showing some casual camaraderie with Curtin.
Laughs derisively at the plan to carry another man's packs, reveals intention to take all the gold for themselves, shows a scheming, selfish mindset.
Engages with Curtin in conversation, sharing thoughts openly though with selfish intent.
Refuses to take any grain from the old man's goods despite Curtin's insistence; insists on working alone without outside help or buddies.
Dismisses Curtin's concern about respecting what the old man honestly worked for, telling him to 'get off your soapbox' and mocking him.
Accuses Curtin of planning to kill him and steal their goods, shows deep suspicion and mistrust.
Immediately draws gun on Curtin and threatens to shoot him, shows aggression and lack of trust.
Commands Curtin to raise his hands, asserts dominance through intimidation.
Sneers at Curtin when he disarms Curtin's gun and refuses to trust or reconcile.
Spits and withdraws to his place by the fire after confrontation, showing disdain and coldness.
Rejects idea of separating peacefully or trusting Curtin, implying suspicion and hostility.
Disarms Curtin after a surprise blow and confidently regains control by stepping back and holding guns pointed at Curtin.
Sneers and spits when Curtin disarms and disarms his gun, then calmly returns to his place by the fire showing control of the situation.
Refuses to separate or negotiate, expresses suspicion and distrust logically suggesting he would be vulnerable to ambush if he separated, indicating tactical awareness.
Laughs and makes a joking bet about someone falling asleep first.
Halts and stands aside on the trail, letting Curtin pass ahead, obeys Curtin's request with a grin.
Grabs Curtin brutally by the collar and forces him to keep marching despite Curtin's exhaustion and pleas for rest
Shoots Curtin after he falls, then checks if Curtin is seriously hurt before returning to campfire without showing concern
Grabs Curtin brutally by the collar and forces him to keep moving despite exhaustion
Shoots Curtin when he fails to comply
Sits and stares into the fire quietly after the confrontation
Checks if Curtin is dead but hesitates to touch him fully, shows uncertainty and cautiousness, does not kill outright though he gives Curtin another shot to be sure.
Returns to the campfire and silently broods, shivers from cold, does not express concern or distress for others, focused on his own survival.
Shows fear and nervousness upon hearing a scream but pulls himself together and continues leading the burros.
Shouts at the burros and has to repeatedly manage and correct their behavior, demonstrating responsibility and persistence.
Engages in a self-argument, reflecting internal conflict and possible insecurity.
Shows concern about the fate of a dead man, hesitates before digging, and is appalled by the sight of buzzards circling overhead.
Considers carefully whether or not to bury the body and thinks through the risks of it being found by animals and others.
Hesitates briefly before rushing through thorny brambles and physical obstacles to reach the place where the body was supposed to be.
Realizes the body is not at the spot where he expected it to be and is momentarily disoriented.
Calls out anxiously for Curtin, showing concern.
Laughs delightedly after figuring out a solution and shoots Curtin without remorse; mocks the tragic death.
Handles the canteen carefully, drinks sparingly, shows signs of distress about their harsh environment.
Savagely jerks the burros and shouts at them loudly in frustration.
Made off with the whole train carrying the gold, betraying his partners.
Shown as not a 'real killer' and 'almost honest' compared to others in a violent context.
Makes off with the whole train carrying more than a hundred thousand (presumably in gold) and heads north, effectively stealing a large amount of treasure.
His act of stealing creates dangerous consequences and conflicts (shooting Curtin), implying poor judgment in managing partnerships and trust.
Is described indirectly as being 'not a real killer' and 'as honest as the next fellow or almost,' showing some ability to bluff or appear competent and not purely villainous.
Shares water and refreshes himself at the pool, laughs with delight at relief from suffering.
Mumbles incoherently and struggles alone with harsh physical and mental torment without seeking help.
Despite physical suffering and disorientation, he navigates off the road to find water and regains composure by drinking and cleansing himself.
Mumbles incoherently due to dry mouth and swollen lips, indicating a moment of extreme physical and mental vulnerability.
Appears uncomfortable and unable to convincingly explain the brand on the burros; sweat pouring off him.
Loses possession of his gun unnoticed, which is taken by a villager.
Looks around at his partners when embarrassed and exposed.
Ignores Curtin's question, showing evasiveness rather than clear communication.
Remains engaged in the search and interprets the situation involving the bandits' deception with costalitos (little bags).
Does not clarify or strategically respond to the confusing situation of lost goods, allowing Howard to lead.
